page.title: 16BUILDINGS IN FELTWELL
page.content: The oldest buildings in the village are around St. Nicholas' church and near the centre of Feltwell. The oldest ones are built of clunch, which is blocks of chalk, dug from pits locally. Some are flint and brick mixed together. Many houses have tie bars to hold them together. There is one house with a thatched roof and very many with very steep roofs because they used to be thatched. Most of the Georgian houses around the village are farmhouses. There are not many Victorian houses in Feltwell. New houses were built on the R.A.F. Base in the 1940s. Western close has council houses built after the war. There are three large new estates built in the 1960s and 70s; mostly of brick with concrete tiles on the roof instead of the Norfolk pantiles which the older houses have.
